title: Early Modern Natural Law: Grotius to Locke
description: The secularization of natural law theory from medieval Scholasticism to Enlightenment natural rights. Grotius establishes international law, Pufendorf develops duties from sociability, Aquinas bridges ancient and modern, and Locke grounds property in labor.
intellectualProgression: Aquinas: Natural law as participation in eternal law (medieval synthesis)
Grotius: Secularizes natural law, founds international law
Pufendorf: Entia moralia, duties from sociability
Locke: Natural rights (life, liberty, property), labor theory, limited government
researchValue: Documents the crucial transition from medieval natural law to Enlightenment natural rights theory. Foundation for classical liberal political philosophy and modern human rights discourse.
